headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Fastenal Company's Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. Now I'll turn the conference over to Ellen Trester of Investor Relatio
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Fastenal Company's Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. Now I'll turn the conference over to Ellen Trester of Investor Relations. Please begin.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Fastenal Company 2012 third quarter earnings conference call. Present for today's call are Will Oberton, our Chief Executive Officer; Dan Florness, our Chief Financial Officer; and Lee hang, our President. The call will last for up to 45 mi
componenttext:
Welcome to the Fastenal Company 2012 third quarter earnings conference call. Present for today's call are Will Oberton, our Chief Executive Officer; Dan Florness, our Chief Financial Officer; and Lee hang, our President. The call will last for up to 45 minutes. The call will start with a general overview of our quarterly results in operations by O-mac and Dan open for questions and answers. Today's conference call is a proprietary Fastenal presentation is being recorded and Fastenal. No recording, reproduction transmission and distribution of today's call is permitted without Fastenal's consent. This call is being audio simulcast on the Internet via the Fastenal Investor Relations homepage, investor.fastenal.com. A replay of the webcast will be available on the website until December 1, 2012, at midnight Central Time. 
As a reminder, today's conference call includes statements regarding the company's anticipated financial and operating results as well as other forward-looking statements based on current expectations as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements may often be identified with words such as we expect, we anticipate, upcoming or similar indications of future expectations. It is important to note that the company's actual results may differ material from those anticipated. Information on factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements are contained in the company's periodic filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and we encourage you to review those carefully. Investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance on such forward-looking statements as there is no assurance that the matter contained in such statements will occur. Forward-looking statements are made as of today's date only, and we undertake no duty to update the information provided on this call. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Will Oberton. Go ahead, Mr. Oberton.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you, Ellen, and good morning, everybody, and thanks for joining our call. I'm going to spend a few minutes of brief comments in my view of the quarter and then I'm going to turn it over to Dan. Overall, I felt that we did a very good
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you, Ellen, and good morning, everybody, and thanks for joining our call. I'm going to spend a few minutes of brief comments in my view of the quarter and then I'm going to turn it over to Dan. 
Overall, I felt that we did a very good job in the quarter considering a little bit of economic headwind. Sales were slow, but we did see an uptick in September, so we're very optimistic about that. Another thing on a positive note is on a sequential basis, from June to September, we're really on track with what our historical numbers are, so we also see that as a positive. We had a very weak April, May time frame although we lost a lot of ground for the year, but since then, we've really been tracking very consistent. So there is a little life underneath all of this. 
We've seen very slow growth in both Asia and Europe. That's also been holding us back. If you compare it to last year, in 2011, we actually were getting about a 200 basis point bump in our sales because of our foreign activity, and this year, it's about equal to the U.S. business, so just not getting any tailwind from our Asia and European businesses. 
Mexico remains very strong, which is very positive. They did great over the last 4 years and we continued to invest, we've opened 7 stores in the last year in Mexico and continue to perform at a very high level. 
A little bit on some of the vertical markets. Construction actually bounced back a little bit in September, but if you look at the number, August was like a low point. And so September is more on a normal number or more a traditional number, almost 10% growth in the construction. In manufacturing, we just haven't seen much change. I think it went -- moved about 10 basis points over the 3-month period, up 10, down 10 so manufacturing has been very consistent, which we actually look as a positive because it has been moving down prior to that, so we're holding our own in manufacturing, and hopefully, things will pick up as time goes on here. 
On the margin -- I'm a little disappointed in the margin. We've been working very hard on improving our margin. We didn't lose any ground. We also didn't make up much ground in the quarter. One thing to note on that, though, is steel remains soft. If you follow the steel markets at all, steel continues to decline a little bit. If you look at -- we look at the Asian steel markets because a lot of our fasteners come out of Asia and a lot of their prices are down, 10% to 20% from a year ago. And so that continues to put pressure on our margins. I think the team is doing a good job of holding the price lift best as they can, but it's more difficult to make gains in a deflationary market. And as fasteners making close to 50% of our business, that makes a big difference in our margin opportunities. But we'll continue to work on that and believe we will show some improvement as we go forward. 
Some of the other projects or initiatives that we're working on, we continue to work hard in metal working. Our goal during the end of the year was to grow that business. The product line, metalworking product line had at least 10 points faster than the overall Fastenal growth. We've been able to maintain that, actually exceed that goal. We continue to make nice wins, still not a huge business for us, but it's a nice sized business and it's growing, meaningfully faster than the overall business, so we're optimistic and our margins have maintained at a nice level. We're not giving up a lot of price to get that sales and we're not getting the sales on price, so that's very positive for us and we'll continue to invest heavily on the metalworking business. 
On the government side, another one of our new initiatives, our goal is the same in government, grow the business at least 10% faster than Fastenal. We're also exceeding those goals, that business, tremendous upside and we'll continue to invest. We continue to make nice wins there. That's going to be -- it's almost regard, it's like streetfighting, it's a door-to-door business, you have to go to a lot of small entities, county shops and small hospitals and city shops, very good, dependable business but it's hard to get, so it's not one big swing gets it all, so we're working very hard in the government business and continue to develop our people in train them and how to go after that business because it is a little different than our traditional industrial and construction business. 
Vending had a very strong quarter. We have very strong quarter in vending. We signed over 5,300 machines. We installed just under 4,000 machines so we've made nice progress in both areas. Some of the positives -- things that I see as positives are we've had broader participation at the store level. We're getting more stores to buy the end of the program. We still have ways to go there, the stores that have bought in earlier, the early adopters are signing far more machines than the rest. It is broadening out and we've also made some very nice customer wins that we've picked up over the last 3  to 4 months, so we're optimistic about what's going on there. We believe it will continue to grow in the future, and as a company, we will continue to invest in the vending program as we will in the metalworking and government programs. 
On the 'pathway to profit', again, a little disappointed there. We only picked up 50 basis points year-over-year. Our goal was 100 basis points, but we really didn't have the sales growth to make it happen. We need probably north of 16%, 15% to 16% sales growth to pick up 100 basis points without squeezing the business too hard and other things. On a positive note, if you look at a 2-year run, we're up 190 basis points. We're still staying pretty close to the goal over a longer period and that's really what we wanted to do. We know we're going to have some strong years and some weaker years. So as a project, we're doing nice, the team is doing a great job, I believe, and we believe we can stay on that track going forward. 
Expense control, done a nice job considering we didn't have the great sales growth that -- as good a sales growth as we're expecting. But I think the team tested a nice job looking at stuff and that's how we've been able to maintain the earnings growth that we have. 
Strong cash flow, Dan and his team did a great job with that, controlling the inventory growth and creating very positive cash flow for the company. So overall, I believe we had a good quarter. I think there's a lot of work to do, a lot of things we can do better. We're very focused on improving our business and growing into the future. 
With that, I'm going to turn it over to Dan because Dan will provide more color on the quarter.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Will, and thanks, everybody for joining us on today's conference call. A couple of things to make note as we flip through the various pages of the press release. On Page 1, inserted a paragraph in this quarter, atypical for us, but the calendar ha
componenttext:
Thanks, Will, and thanks, everybody for joining us on today's conference call. A couple of things to make note as we flip through the various pages of the press release. On Page 1, inserted a paragraph in this quarter, atypical for us, but the calendar had some impact on the quarter, so I wanted to share a few thoughts on that. 
In the third quarter, we actually had 63 days versus 64 days a year ago. And in some businesses, that might not make much of a difference, but for us, when you're selling a very tangible product, the number of business days really does matter. Our headline number is we grew our sales at 10.5%, but if you really peer under the hood a little bit, look at our daily growth, that's over 12%. I think that's a number that's relevant because that's the number that carries the trend into the future. And so I added a little comment blurb on that. 
Looking at that 10%, very pleased, and Will mentioned very pleased the fact that we were able to obtain leverage in an environment where we could grew top line dollars growing at 10% and had a little bit of a headwind from the gross profit side as well. 
One item just to make notable, when I look into Q4, we will have, it's a 63 to 63-day quarter so nothing going on from that standpoint. There is a bit of movement among months of the quarter. October will have 23 days this year versus 21 a year ago, so a nice headline number. Daily will probably suffer a little bit because of that just because there's a certain piece of our business that's more centered on the month and there's piece to our business that's more centered on the day. So just to make everybody aware that there is 2 additional days. Those 2 days we give back in December. So if I look at trade-offs in life, October is a big month for us, and if I can get 2 extra days in October and get them back in December, I'll take that deal anytime. 
Will touched on the sequential patterns love that we looked at on Page 3 in the release. If you look at the last couple of years, 2010 and 2011, we were beating the benchmark pattern that we laid out, 50%, 60%, 70% of the time, and we go out to September, we were 490 basis points ahead of the trend line, so 5 points ahead of the trendline, year-to-date, looking at January to September. This year, we have a setback in February, some weather issues going on. We quickly got it back in March, but then May came along and May really changed the year for us and created more conservative tones within the organization for the balance of the year. And at the end of June, we were about 330 basis points behind year-to-date history, and we're basically at that same point we've got 330 basis points behind, now it's September. So since June, the business has been kind of treading water as far as compared to history, but nice momentum nice pickup, as Will mentioned, as we signed September. And that bodes well as we go into October and into 2013, the more important way of looking at it. 
In that context of the April, May, June timeframe when we did see the slowdown, it was really in the faster area. The non-fastener area held up much better, but that's also the area that's helped by all the growth drivers, the vending, the government business, the metalworking, all those things we're doing really demonstrated that we can work through a period of declining economy and maintain very attractive top line growth rates. 
One thing, in September here, ISM did pop up. Historically, when we look at ISM, and we've always felt ISM led us by about 3 months, so if ISM drops in June, we expect to see a drop in September. What we've been seeing in really the last year, year and a half is, that we kind of coincide with ISM. I'm not quite sure what caused the change, but when we dropped off in May, the ISM dropped off in June. I'm going to see if the ISM was over 51 in September is a blip about some legs. I think essentially the jury's still out for us. We're still maintaining a conservative tone as we go into the tailwind of the year and into the first part of 2013. 
As Will mentioned, on the growth drivers, on Page 6, all I can say in the FAST Solutions is, really nice quarter, great signings. I attribute that to great focus on it at the field level. Our stores, our districts, our regionals are really running with this. Russ Rubie and his team does a great job. We're very pleased with that. To me, that gives the piece that jumps out the most, is the fact that obviously, this is wrapping up quickly, but we have a fair number of machines that have been out there for 12, 18, 24 months. That's not an inconsequential number, and the fact that, that entire group of customers that have vending overlapping numbers come is still growing faster than 30%, I think is a staggering figure and demonstrates the power of what vending can mean for our business. It's really about customer engagement. Vending is just the way we measure it. It's about we are engaged with that group of customers and we're growing because we're providing great service and great value for them. 
In that same section of growth drivers, Will touched on a bit of 2013, we set out some expectations for store openings for next year, indicated a range of 50 to 100, which is about 2% to 4%. And I think our focus, really, is continuing the growth drivers we have in 2011 and 2012. They're demonstrating great results. We integrate fasteners. We have some things that we're working on to really drive our OEM fastener growth. And in July, we mentioned the elevation of Lee to President and I think we announced that after the call last quarter, so I'm going to congratulate Lee on his promotion. But I think the final thing we've touched on that paragraph was talking about fixing our underperforming stores. And when I think of people and their strengths that they bring to the table, one of the things that I think when I think of Lee, he's great at assessing people and talent and he's great at raising the bar. And if you're driving down the road and with your car and your brake is stuck on one of your tires, it's going to slow you down. And we have a subset of stores that are growing in aren't performing and we need to raise the bar and get that brake off because it damages the rest of the engine, and I'm pretty excited about that looking to 2013. 
Profit drivers of the business on Page 7, continue to be pleased with the progress of 'pathway to profit'. We took a step back a little bit in some of the smaller groups. I think there's really 2 things that are driving that, one working on and another one is probably a good problem, one is the gross margin that Will touched on. We're down in gross margin as a percent year-over-year. That creates a drag in all those groups of stores. The other thing is, we're preventing a rolling out in the smaller stores, the expense that vending does put a little drag on their pretax, but I think that's a good problem from the standpoint that really is driving our growth. But if you look at the stores that do more than 150,000 a month, where there is no vending impact, I mean, negative vending impact because the dollars is expensed not big enough, well, that group is impressive and we saw nice profit growth on a year-over-year basis. 
The other thing I think to think about, and I touched on it in last quarter call as well, if you look at since we started the 'pathway to profit' back in 2007, we have increased the size of Fastenal by about 65%. We improved our gross margin from 51% to 51.6% and our profits have doubled not just talking about the power of growth, leverage it with improving gross profit and managing your fixed operating expenses and leveraging quite effectively. 
If you look -- looking at our expenses in the organization, we guys talked about our biggest operating expenses is the people side of the equation. And if I look at what we've done since 2007, we've added around 3,800 people to our organization since the first quarter of 2007. 87% of those adds are in roles that directly contact, that interact with customers every day. 6% are involved in our distribution centers, 6% are involved in our manufacturing. So if I add those 3 up, 99% of our headcount growth since 2007 is in those 3 areas, and that's how you leverage overhead in an organization. 
I'm very pleased with the fact that we hit 21.9, I'm just going to round up and say 22, it just feels better, but again, those are 2 highly profitable quarters for us despite the fact that we didn't have great sales growth in the quarter. We continue to make progress on our exclusive brands. We're essentially at 10% of sales to date. Vending really is nothing move that number. 
And then finally, I'll touch on some working capital. Will mentioned continued improvement on working capital. Now I do want to mention that Scott and his team really did a nice job, I think, year-to-date on managing the distribution side of the inventory. We lost a little traction on the accounts receivable side. Part of that was a short September, takes x number of days to cross paths and there's enough of August business that's coming in the first week of October. That's more a calendar issue. But when I look at cash flow, year-to-date, we've taken 90% of our earnings and turned it into operating cash. We've spent about 27% of earnings on CapEx. A big piece of that relates to the success we're seeing in vending and we've thrown off 63% of our earnings in free cash flow year-to-date. Great number, and because of that, we did announce last night an increased store dividend and are paying out a $0.21 dividend fourth quarter. 
With that, I'll turn it over to quick questions might come up.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from Hamzah Mazari of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from Hamzah Mazari of Credit Suisse.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: The first question is just on store growth. You've talked about 2% to 4% growth next year. How should investors think about that number? Is that more of a normalized growth rate for you guys on stores? Or do you plan on increasing store growth if you get
componenttext: The first question is just on store growth. You've talked about 2% to 4% growth next year. How should investors think about that number? Is that more of a normalized growth rate for you guys on stores? Or do you plan on increasing store growth if you get more comfortable on the economy? Just curious to see how we should think about store growth given where Fastenal is right now.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm going to be perfectly honest. I don't know that we know, and I'll say that in a couple of ways. We still don't know yet from our non-North American business what that means for store openings into the future. We just don't know. If I center the answer
componenttext: I'm going to be perfectly honest. I don't know that we know, and I'll say that in a couple of ways. We still don't know yet from our non-North American business what that means for store openings into the future. We just don't know. If I center the answer on North America, what we know about the market is it's big, $140 billion, it's $150 billion, it's $160 billion year, depending on whose math you're looking at and we have somewhere between 2% and 3% market share. And historically, a lot of our eggs are in the store opening basket. And with the 'pathway to profit', we really took a step away from that and said, there's a whole bunch of ways for us to go out and go after this market share and we have this network that's out there that is -- that has unbelievable capabilities and that's balanced our total growth drivers across more channels, so we put tools in the hand, not just of an area where we're more sparse but an area where we're more dense. I mean, with a look at the growth, we continue to see in the upper Midwest in a business that we've been in for 40-plus years. And we're dealing with a combination of store openings, vending, government, the whole gamut as far as growth drivers. We think 2% to 4% is a good number for 2013. 2014 and 2015, we'll see when we get there. Long way over not really answer your question, but seeing the opportunity is so big that we don't want to paint ourselves into the corner and say it has to go from this one thing. It comes from a variety. But when I think of, for example, the government business, and I don't know in our products how big the government is, but if you read the headline, the government is 20% of our economy. So if we have 2,500 locations, I'm figuring out the math in my head, and we had a 20% potential to that, that's like opening 500 stores. So is that a better route to go down in the short term or is it a goal of store openings? I think it's a combination of the 2, but I'll take that government business.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful and I appreciate it. Just one last follow-up question. On vending, could you maybe talk about how you're vending offering is different from some of your largest -- larger competitors? Specifically, is your machine different, what are y
componenttext: That's very helpful and I appreciate it. Just one last follow-up question. On vending, could you maybe talk about how you're vending offering is different from some of your largest -- larger competitors? Specifically, is your machine different, what are you stocking in there relative to what others are stocking? Do you own the inventory? Does the customer own the inventory? I know there's a better difference between your offering and some of your competition, maybe if you could touch on that.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Will. I think a lot of them is quite similar. Our machines are Internet-based appliances, which we think is an advantage because they're more dependable. Some of the other companies offer a machine that has a PC built into it. It seems less than w
componenttext: This is Will. I think a lot of them is quite similar. Our machines are Internet-based appliances, which we think is an advantage because they're more dependable. Some of the other companies offer a machine that has a PC built into it. It seems less than what we used to offer for 5 years ago and we find out these are far more dependable. Because it's up PC-based appliance come it's also lower cost system and so we're able to provide them at somewhat lower cost. The inventory in some customers is consigned inventory and other customers choose to own but a majority is consigned. Some of our competition does consigned inventory and some of them have the customers own it. I think one of our biggest advantages compared to the big public companies that we all know of is our local branch network because this a physical business. If you think about the person who's supplying your soda machines or slot machines in the office, those people are driving from 3 or 4 hours in many cases. Our local branch have the service element. It's going to be very hard to duplicate for some of our competitors. I know some of our competitors, their strategy is to shift at the end of the factory and that the factory workers put the product away. But I guess if you're the person regretting the vending machines in your office, you ship the product in the dock and you guys can put it away in the morning, probably you will find a new supplier. So we have that local advantage that really gives us some leverage and we have this distribution network to move the product more efficiently. But machine to machine, product to product, it's not that dissimilar.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from David Manthey from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from David Manthey from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: First off, Dan, back in the third quarter of last year, you said that you could take your leverage probably down to maybe 12% or 13% growth with energy and you said lower if you hit the wall and it seems like you're taking a leverage point down to that le
componenttext: First off, Dan, back in the third quarter of last year, you said that you could take your leverage probably down to maybe 12% or 13% growth with energy and you said lower if you hit the wall and it seems like you're taking a leverage point down to that level or lower and I'm just wondering about the strength you saw here in September relative to an uncertain economy. Are you happy with where the set point is right now that you'll maintain that unless things change one way or the other in 2013? That's the first question. And then just take the second one in here, too. In terms of vending placements, the number of vending machines, by my math, is up over 300% in the past year and revenues to customers with vending machines looks like it's up a little bit less than 100% and I'm trying to understand that dynamic. Does that mean you're now getting to smaller customers? Are you placing more of the fast, FAST 3000 machines with less yield per customer? What is the implication from that math?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. First off, a coupled of different questions there. First, on the breakpoint, my comment a year ago, '12 and '13, I'm glad to say I was wrong. I think part of it is I'm Midwestern and I'm an accountant so it probably makes me too conservative and not
componenttext: Okay. First off, a coupled of different questions there. First, on the breakpoint, my comment a year ago, '12 and '13, I'm glad to say I was wrong. I think part of it is I'm Midwestern and I'm an accountant so it probably makes me too conservative and not willing to put my neck out and we can get to 10% because I don't think we could. So I think that's good execution especially on the face of the gross profit dynamic going on which made it more challenging. On the vending machine, I'm not sure if I'm following your math on the 100% pieces. And in fact, I'll kind of restate it back the way we have it and I think I'll allow that and I'll give you a third question to follow up on my answer. But when you think about it is, the customers that are coming into that group when we introduced vending, our -- that overall business is growing up 30% and that includes the weight, if you will, of the customers that have anniversaried, the customers that have been there a year ago or 2 years ago because we're looking at that combine group. I think if you're talking about vending being up over 100 because you're looking at the new machines and the dollars going through it, you're just taking the math saying, okay, 24% of your sales of the customers are vending and that number is x percent bigger than it was a year ago, you're comparing apples and oranges because we have customers that we had a year ago that didn't have vending that have vending today. And so when we talk about a percentage of our sales that is vending, that includes customers that have been buying for us for years. We're just now looking at it and saying how big is that pool growing and how big was that customer base a year ago, and which I think the best way to look at it, because it's really how much is it impacting your business, not what is the dollar growth on a machine because that's really not a meaningful number. I'm not sure if I answered your question, but again, the other thing I get a look at it and say if I look at our dollars per machine and I try to understand that dynamic, is it improving or getting worse, it's at or better than it was a year ago. And so from that standpoint, I don't think there's any dilution going on because of the different models of machines, but there is some impact. When we report our machine count, we're reporting just our absolute count, any machines we have out there. And in that mix, there's the traditional FAST 5000, there's the locker systems, there's the hydration machines, I think that's what we call it, and there are some cutting tool machines, so there's a variety of machines and they have different potentials as far as throughput. And the way we measure it is we look at lockers and we say, we think they have about a 1/2 of a potential. So when we're looking at $1 for machine we look at that as a  1/2. But I don't know if I just thought out loud did it bring -- did it answer your question maybe Will has a better answer.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: The way I look at it, Dave, look at incremental growth of this group of customers. This group of customers represented almost 60%. If you take 25, roughly 25% of your business, grew 20 points faster than the overall company, that represents the majority o
componenttext: The way I look at it, Dave, look at incremental growth of this group of customers. This group of customers represented almost 60%. If you take 25, roughly 25% of your business, grew 20 points faster than the overall company, that represents the majority of our incremental growth. And we lay that against the expense of the vending program. But then from the vending program, we can also look at it in a different way and say, we're putting expense of all these machines into our occupancy because we really think it's just outside storage and our occupancy is not growing our revenue because Dan's group is doing such a great job. We be building this into our old P&L working model and so it's very accretive business when you look at it that way. It's a great growth driver. But we can talk more and try and clear up I'm a little confused as to what the question.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's great. I appreciate the color on that. Just a follow-up on that first question though, Dan, in terms of how you feel about it, as you're looking at the business well for next year, I'm just trying to get a read -- I go tremendous amount of visibili
componenttext: That's great. I appreciate the color on that. Just a follow-up on that first question though, Dan, in terms of how you feel about it, as you're looking at the business well for next year, I'm just trying to get a read -- I go tremendous amount of visibility but there's a lot of cross currents here in terms of the data we're seeing out there in the marketplace them at some of the economic data that relative to what you're seeing for your June, for September and I'm just trying to give a relative read on your feeling as you look to 2013, are you feeling pretty good? Or are you still fairly cautious about this industrial environment just as a company?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're cautious. What we're investing aggressively, I mean, we're putting vending machines out there, we're adding up -- we're adding sales potential into our organization every day, but we are cautious when we're looking at how we manage our expenses.
componenttext: We're cautious. What we're investing aggressively, I mean, we're putting vending machines out there, we're adding up -- we're adding sales potential into our organization every day, but we are cautious when we're looking at how we manage our expenses.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: And one thing that we did mention on the call is, that we've introduced a lot of new technologies and efficiencies into our business that have helped us lower that break-even down somewhere below 10%, I guess, if you look at the numbers. Those are things
componenttext: And one thing that we did mention on the call is, that we've introduced a lot of new technologies and efficiencies into our business that have helped us lower that break-even down somewhere below 10%, I guess, if you look at the numbers. Those are things that will continue to benefit us for a year and it's not our organization, electronic billing and accounting, the automation in our warehouses and we've introduced 2 or 3 major things to the stores from point of sale, simplifying the pricing, simplifying the process of batch processing of orders with the goal of being the most efficient distributor in the industry. These are things that have a longtail on and will continue to benefit, so we're break even does at any given time will depend on our view. And if we're very bullish, we will invest that and that'll slide up. We're very conservative, will come out right now. We're cautiously conservative. We'll pull that down and have a lower number. We have better levers than we've ever had because we're not adding the cost of the fixed overhead in the stores. That was a big thing that you couldn't do much about once you had it so.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Sam Darkatsh of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Sam Darkatsh of Raymond James.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on vending again. So specifically looking at your vending customers, what's the growth that you're seeing from the SKUs that they're buying that don't come from the machines? I'm trying to figure out the -- parse out the actual
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on vending again. So specifically looking at your vending customers, what's the growth that you're seeing from the SKUs that they're buying that don't come from the machines? I'm trying to figure out the -- parse out the actual impacts of the machines themselves on those customers versus what they're doing outside of the machines.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess I'm going to answer it by talking about if I look at the subset of the business that goes through the vending machine, that number is then -- if we had a $10,000 customer, $2,200, $2,300 of that 22%, 23% is physically going to the machine bu
componenttext: Well, I guess I'm going to answer it by talking about if I look at the subset of the business that goes through the vending machine, that number is then -- if we had a $10,000 customer, $2,200, $2,300 of that 22%, 23% is physically going to the machine but the products that are going through the machines, Sam, couldn't be products that -- there's 40 slots in machines. 10 of those slots could be items that we've been selling to the customer for years, and just now we're selling it using the vending machine as a vehicle and the other 30 slots or 20 slots or 10 slots are now new products. But the discussion we have with the customer is really one of economics. We're bringing this machine that we believe will help your business and what we need is a couple of thousand dollars for incremental business with you. And that's usually the worst case scenario, but let's use that scenario where the customer is spending $3,000 a month of business that now is going to 100% will go to the vending machine. And I know based on the value that vending machine brings, that $3,000 spend that we've had with that customer had with us is probably going down to $1,800 or $2,000 because it goes the vending machine there's more accountability to the product. And so our discussion with that customer is, we need, in total, to take your business from $10,000 to $12,000.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're doing $10,000 for that customer.
componenttext: We're doing $10,000 for that customer.

componenttextpreview: Too incremental.
componenttext: Too incremental.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: I need $2,000 incremental, but the discussion might be, the customer says, I've got $3,000 a month welding supply and they turned over to supply stores. We are not lead to machine dynamic. We are led to the growth of the business.
componenttext: I need $2,000 incremental, but the discussion might be, the customer says, I've got $3,000 a month welding supply and they turned over to supply stores. We are not lead to machine dynamic. We are led to the growth of the business.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sam, the other thing that happens from our branch standpoint again to the local branch is because our people are there, daily or every other day, are capturing sales this we are there. We're having customers go, the employee working in a blue shirt with a
componenttext: Sam, the other thing that happens from our branch standpoint again to the local branch is because our people are there, daily or every other day, are capturing sales this we are there. We're having customers go, the employee working in a blue shirt with a blue machine going, that's our supplier. Hey, while you're here, can you give me whatever. We're seeing that growth because of that also, back a little to the store.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me ask a second question then. You've talked in the past about the average size of a customer that uses a vending solution. What is that average size now? How many more customers do you have of that size that have not yet signed up with vending
componenttext: Okay. Let me ask a second question then. You've talked in the past about the average size of a customer that uses a vending solution. What is that average size now? How many more customers do you have of that size that have not yet signed up with vending solutions? And how many customers of that size do you tend to add on an annual basis?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: When we started vending and we looked at the opportunity, and I think that's the best way to answer it, we looked at it and said, we have 230,000, 240,000 active customers a month. And we think about 10% of that number, 25,000 to 30,000, based on our init
componenttext: When we started vending and we looked at the opportunity, and I think that's the best way to answer it, we looked at it and said, we have 230,000, 240,000 active customers a month. And we think about 10% of that number, 25,000 to 30,000, based on our initial definition of the vending, the FAST 5000, could have a vending machine. And we looked at it and said, if we could have 2 machines per customer in that environment, there's opportunity here for us to have 50,000 machines. That was what we thought about it 3 years ago. And so if I think of the -- I don't have exact number in front of me, but we have, what, 17,000 machines out there right now, and the last I think the relationship is about 2 or 2.2 machines per customer, so there's 8,000 customers right now that have vending, rough numbers and we have might have a better number. And so there's a big universe of customers out there that we have today that we put vending into, even based on our definition of 3 years ago if I look at where FAST 5000 is, we've added a whole fleet of machines now and we've brought in the audience of customers that could have vending. We've decreased the size that we need to run through the machine and decrease the size of customer. So I don't think there's a market limitation for us unless you want to start talking out to 2020.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, anecdotally, Sam, when you talk to store managers that had bought into this, they'll tell you basically 3 or 4 customers in the market maybe a potential. And when you visit stores that have done very well, stores that have 20 or 30 machines, and we
componenttext: Well, anecdotally, Sam, when you talk to store managers that had bought into this, they'll tell you basically 3 or 4 customers in the market maybe a potential. And when you visit stores that have done very well, stores that have 20 or 30 machines, and we have several of those now and you ask them what their market potential is, with the lowest numbers I hear are 50. Most of the people say, I'll get well over 100 in my store. So once the store manager starts to see this, the numbers become so much larger. I'm almost shaking my head and well. These are guys in the field, these are the guys that understand it. And so it's really about opening the eyes and the numbers will continue to grow as Dan said as we get different machines for smaller customers and larger customers. It's simply a better way to deliver products.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: There really weren't. One thing I noticed about September, Ryan, is the consistency throughout the United States. If you looked at the growth region by region, it was probably the narrowest group that you've seen in a long time. Nobody had a real bad mont
componenttext: There really weren't. One thing I noticed about September, Ryan, is the consistency throughout the United States. If you looked at the growth region by region, it was probably the narrowest group that you've seen in a long time. Nobody had a real bad month and there's really no one that had a great month which consistency is good for us. We did see a nice uptick well in our international business. Part of that was driven by currency, but overall, even that was up internationally. So it was consistent. It was, for the most part, consistent through the month. We had a little bit of a stronger finish, but we do our daily analysis and we bring the sales in and we ended up about 200 basis points ahead of where we had estimated even before halfway through the month. Some of the days into the month we were estimating in that high 12s and that's where we ended up a little bit about 12.9. So very consistent pattern, consistent across the United States and steady is the month went, so that was all positive.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012

componenttext: That sounds actually very positive. Okay, and then second question, last vending now but I'm going to ask a different way. Is that the right way to think about it? Is that how you're thinking about it?

componenttext: The impact is going to continue to grow because the number of machines is growing so fast, and so it adds in new layers of potential.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think the other thing, and we don't know how to measure this, is there's a lot of built-up -- I mean, there's a lot of energy going into this project today, but it's really delayed because it takes us about 90 days to install a machine after we sign it
componenttext: I think the other thing, and we don't know how to measure this, is there's a lot of built-up -- I mean, there's a lot of energy going into this project today, but it's really delayed because it takes us about 90 days to install a machine after we sign it and it really takes another 60 to 90 days to get everything flowing because what happens in most cases is, the customers we sign up have a lot of inventory, whether we we sell it to them or the other guys did, they have a stock that we have to burn through, and many times, we actually put more machines and burn the inventory through charge or theirs. So the reality is, if I design a machine today, it's probably March before I see much again. So we have a lot of energy and selling that has a delayed, positive effect because that's actually a great thing because it will come through. The other part -- the other with all that energy will probably not looking as hard and to some other things we should because we only have so many hours in a day, so it's really worth your time. And as Dan mentioned fasteners, they're offering -- Lee to comment.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 11, 2012
componenttextpreview: What I would add also, Ryan, is, we are focusing on the participation, what we can accelerate vending or the vending sales because more stores are participating. There, every time you look at Tassell, whether it's government, any of our industry specialis
componenttext: What I would add also, Ryan, is, we are focusing on the participation, what we can accelerate vending or the vending sales because more stores are participating. There, every time you look at Tassell, whether it's government, any of our industry specialists, you always have to hold that against how many stores are participating in this growth driver today and that's really where we come in to drive that once the stores latch onto vending, we get the majority of stores participating in that is where we'll accelerate that.
